summary: This is a motion in limine filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team seeking to exclude 'Government Exhibit 52' from her criminal trial. The motion argues the 97-page document is unauthenticated hearsay with questionable provenance, allegedly surfacing in 2009 through former Epstein employee Alfredo Rodriguez who tried to sell it to a lawyer. The defense claims the document cannot be authenticated, is not a business record, and is prejudicial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case who is filing this motion to exclude evidence. Referred to as 'Ms. Maxwell' throughout.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: A deceased former employee of Jeffrey Epstein who allegedly attempted to sell the document compilation (Exhibit 52) to lawyer Brad Edwards in 2009. He was convicted of obstruction and attempting to extort money from lawyers representing plaintiffs against Epstein.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: A lawyer involved in suing Jeffrey Epstein in 2009. Alfredo Rodriguez allegedly approached him to sell evidence against Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from HADDON, MORGAN & FOREMAN P.C., one of the signatories on the motion.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from HADDON, MORGAN & FOREMAN P.C., listed on the motion.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from COHEN & GRESSER LLP, listed on the motion.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Law Offices of Bobbi C. Sternheim, listed on the motion.

persons.name: Nicole Simmons
persons.context: Person who certified service of the motion on October 18, 2021.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'Mr. Epstein'. The document in question (Exhibit 52) allegedly contains evidence against him, and Rodriguez tried to sell it to lawyers suing him.

persons.name: Detective Joe Recarey
persons.context: Mentioned in Rodriguez's deposition testimony as the detective to whom Rodriguez gave a journal and information regarding the case. The motion notes the 97-page exhibit is not what was given to this detective.

connections.description: Implied by the context of the criminal case; Maxwell is charged with conspiracy related to Epstein's activities.
Rodriguez was a former employee of Epstein, as stated in the motion.
Rodriguez approached Edwards to sell the document compilation for $50,000, leading to an FBI sting operation.
Pagliuca is listed as an attorney for Maxwell and signed the motion.
Menninger is listed as an attorney for Maxwell on the motion.
Everdell is listed as an attorney for Maxwell on the motion.
Sternheim is listed as an attorney for Maxwell on the motion.

events.title: Rodriguez Attempts to Sell Documents
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez, a former Epstein employee, approaches lawyer Brad Edwards and offers to sell a 97-page document compilation allegedly containing evidence against Jeffrey Epstein for $50,000. An FBI sting operation is set up where Rodriguez provides the pages to an undercover officer.

events.title: Deposition of Alfredo Rodriguez
events.description: Rodriguez is deposed (Vol. II). He testifies about a journal with names of girls, which he claims he gave to Detective Joe Recarey, and states he could not find any documents at his house in response to a subpoena.

events.title: Criminal Case Against Rodriguez
events.description: A criminal complaint is filed against Alfredo Rodriguez (Case No. 9:09-mj-08308-LRJ) for obstruction and attempting to extort money from lawyers representing plaintiffs against Epstein. He is later convicted.

events.title: Filing of Motion in Limine
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files this motion to exclude Government Exhibit 52 from her criminal trial, arguing it is unauthenticated hearsay.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza New York NY 10007
keyFacts: Government Exhibit 52 is a 97-page document compilation that the defense seeks to exclude, arguing it is unauthenticated hearsay from suspect sources.

The document allegedly surfaced in 2009 when former Epstein employee Alfredo Rodriguez tried to sell it to lawyer Brad Edwards for $50,000, leading to an FBI sting and Rodriguez's conviction for obstruction.
The defense argues the document has no identified author, date of creation, or custodian, appears photocopied and altered, and may have been manipulated by Rodriguez for financial gain.
The document contains an unexplained notation 'P.B., 2004-2005' which is the only potential date reference, but it surfaced years after the alleged conspiracies (which ended in 2004).
In a 2009 deposition, Rodriguez testified he gave a journal with names of girls to Detective Joe Recarey and had no such documents at his house, contradicting the provenance of Exhibit 52.
